comment.author: 8706669@N05
comment._content: Well, in fact must be write REVILLAGIGEDO. I live in Mexico anda that's the way here is named.

comment.author: 34904489@N07
comment._content:
Wystan and Pastor Delgado:

Thanks to both of you for the proper spelling of this road in Mexico. We will correct it when we update the record.

comment.author: 53461717@N08
comment._content:
I wonder when and where in Revillagigedo [pronounce reveeyaheehedo] 
was taken. Now a days this street runs  south-north from Arcos de Belén to Juárez.  In the corner with Victoria there used to be located a fortress-like building which was Mexico City Police Headquarter.  Across Arcos de Belen heading south, the street takes the name General G. Hernández up to Dr. Río de la Loza, where Cárcel de Belem (Belem Prison) was located (today there is found PGJ building [Procuraduría General de Justicia]).  It was most likely taken in February 1913, during the 10 Tragic Days (Decena Trágica) when both buildings were warded by federals.  Quite near was the Ciudadela (Fire arms mill), which was sieged and heavy combats took place. Although trees on background make believe they are close (two or three blocks) to La Alameda.  So for that, is the most likely position, therefore is Revillagigedo between calle Nuevo México (today Artículo 123), behind the camera and Calle Independencia on the background.
Dr. Roberto Duarte
Plastic Surgeon

comment.author: 53461717@N08
comment._content: There's a photo that was taken practically at the same time and slightly the same angle so we can say both pictures are "twins". Entitled as Federal battery (Federal Troops). Digital Collections > Getty Research Institute Exhibitions > A Nation Emerges: Sixty-five Years of Photography in Mexico Accession/ID Number gri_mexico_98_r_30_32a Of the two pictures there, the bottom one. I added that picture to my Photostream you can find it if you click in www.flickr.com/photos/jesusduarte/7198452118/in/photostream That makes most likely the location I mentioned in the previous comment. Dr. Roberto Duarte

comment.author: 53461717@N08
comment._content: In fotografosdelarevolucion.blogspot.mx/2009/10/domingo-16.html It says this picture was taken on February Sunday 16, 1913, between 11 and 12 am. At Revillagigedo and Victoria (that is one block back east from Nuevo Mexico Street, previously mentioned).

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/70251312@N00] 
Yes it is true.  But the techincal aspects, for The Library of Congress cataloguers, matter less than the historic background.   They matter for both photographs match because were taken at the same site, in the same time and to the same people.
Greetings Wystan, from
